instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2849: What is 820-2849? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.ADAPTER_EN: What is ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
I came to this from testing power rails, all s5 present all s3 missing 
visual inspection reveals nothing except for cum stains around the backside usb connectors
<RESISTOR>R5222</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5223</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5012</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5044</RESISTOR> all discolored 
the rest looks fine, board was ultrasonic cleaned after initial inspection

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR> <RESISTOR>R5481</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R5482</RESISTOR>
ran wire from rin 1 <RESISTOR>R5481</RESISTOR> to pin 4 <TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR>
replaced Y2605
I have a genuine 85W charger for both magsafe L and 2
ppbus 1.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Pfff you are measuring <SIGNAL>SLP_S4</SIGNAL> while PPBUS is not even there? Why?

Resistance to GND on PPBUS? Resistance between pins 17/18, 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is what is used to create <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> which is the voltage line the PCH uses for all of the 3.3v logic signals such as <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>. Fix <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> first!

threads.message: Hmm... Loads of liquid near <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. I wonder what creates <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
clarification, on intake ppbus was present, now its not
resistance to ground ppbus@F7074 0.8k
resistance between <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> pin 17/18   3ohms
resistance between <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> pin 27/28  20ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: that's 800 ohms to ground. It should be way higher. That is going to be a crappy short to find, but I would start by injecting voltage and seeing what heats up. Can you remove F7040 and see what side the short is on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
short is on the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> side, pin 1
ive removed <CAPACITOR>C7040</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7045</CAPACITOR>
dc power supply only pulling 0.031A
pulled off <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>
put heat over <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and it exploded
replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and everything else I removed
short to ground on ppbus is gone, now strange behaviour
when I plug in the charger it starts at 13.5volts and stays for like 10 seconds and then drops to 2volts
---------------edit-------------------------
pad 17 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> missing, ran wire from pin 17 <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to pin 1 <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> now ppbus is a steady 12.3volts

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is now 0.896 volts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: SMC is not working, check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> if it is ok could be crap under SMC (do a reflow) or dead SMC (replace SMC)....... .

threads.message: me too, ive got donor boards but no stencil so ive ordered stencils from aliexpress

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You do not need a stencil for replacing the smc. if you take the smc off super clean and re seat the new one super clean you can do it with out a stencil. i do not have a stencil and i do all smc replacements free hand.  no troubles other than having to take it of and clean it up and putting back on as the balls sometimes fuck up.  i have even replaced smcs with no balls on the board or the smc chip and still successful. really i have never seen anyone else do it like that but it works well for me and takes much less time than messing with a stencil getting the balls perfect and then seating it. give it a try if you like it Thumbs up if not use a stencil.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: no, just no. i dont do anything super clean. ive become really good at reballing, each chip only takes 1-2 minutes
